text: The in Japan was a set of six pretenders to the throne of Japan during the Nanboku-chō period from 1336 through 1392.Nussbaum, Louis Frédéric and Käthe Roth. (2005). "Hokuchō," Japan Encyclopedia, p. 344. ==List of pretenders== *Emperor Kōgon, 1331–1333Nussbaum, "Kōgon Tennō" at p. 543. *Emperor Kōmyō, 1336–1348Nussbaum, "Kōmyō Tennō" at p. 555. *Emperor Sukō, 1348–1351Nussbaum, "Sukō Tennō" at p. 911. *Emperor Go-Kōgon, 1352–1371Nussbaum, "Go-Kōgon Tennō" at p. 255. *Emperor Go-En'yū, 1371–1382Nussbaum, "Go-En'yu Tennō" at p. 251. *Emperor Go-Komatsu, 1382–1412Nussbaum, "Go-Kōmatsu Tennō" at p. 255. After 1392, Go-Komatsu was the 100th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession.. ==List of pretender-created eras== During the Nanboku- chō period, the Northern Court pretenders recognized 19 Japanese era names (年号, nengō, lit. year names), including # Gentoku, 1329–1332 # Shōkyō, 1332–1334 # Kemmu, 1334–1338 # Ryakuō, 1338–1342 # Kōei, 1342–1345 # Jōwa, 1345–1350 # Kannō, 1350–1352 # Bunna, 1352–1356 # Enbun, 1356–1361 # Kōan, 1361–1362 # Jōji, 1362–1368 # Ōan, 1368–1375 # Eiwa, 1375–1379 # Kōryaku, 1379–1381 # Eitoku, 1381–1384 # Shitoku, 1384–1387 # Kakei, 1387–1389 # Kōō, 1389–1390 # Meitoku, 1390–1394 == Related pages== * Southern Court * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese era name == References == ==Other websites== * Metropolitan Museum of Art, Kamakura and Nanbokucho Periods (1185–1392), Muromachi Period (1392–1573) Category:14th century in Japan Category:1336 establishments in Japan Category:1390s disestablishments in Japan Category:1392 disestablishments
title: Northern Court
